I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Asian Development Outlook (ADO), a flagship publication of the Asian Development 
Bank (ADB), is an important vehicle to promote ADB’s knowledge and expertise about the 
region, providing insights into the economic issues faced by Asia and the Pacific. Its content 
informs  ADB  Management  opinion  and  guides  institutional  views  about  the  region’s 
macroeconomic prospects and important development issues. The production of the ADO has 
been regularly supported by technical assistance (TA) funding.1 The objectives, scope, and 
activities to be covered by the regional TA are in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Inclusive economic growth is one of the three development agendas under Strategy 
2020.3 The ADO, by regularly providing comprehensive analysis on evolving developments in 
ADB developing member countries (DMCs), provides a basis for understanding the key drivers 
of and constraints on economic growth—a critical element for inclusive economic growth as a 
priority research area. This important role of flagship publications such as the ADO in monitoring 
the major economic issues and trends of DMCs was recognized in the TA Strategic Forum 2008. 
Also, under ADB’s streamlined business processes, the ADO has become the main reference 
for the economic assessment and outlook section of country partnership strategies.  
 
3.  The ADO is one of the publications most frequently downloaded from ADB’s website.4 It 
is a source of much international and national news commentary that features analysis, views, 
and opinions from ADB. Thus, a concerted effort to produce a high-quality publication every 
year is vital to elevate the publication’s profile and ensure its relevance and usefulness in 
research and policy dialogues and formulation in ADB DMCs. For example, the ADO has 
recently  featured  in-depth  analysis  on  such  topics  as  rebalancing  growth,  macroeconomic 
management beyond the global financial crisis, inequality in developing Asia, and the energy 
challenge in Asia. Discussion of these topics has important policy implications as developing 
Asia strives to sustain long-term growth in the face of global uncertainties. 
 
4.  Rapid economic growth has lifted hundreds of millions of Asians out of poverty and 
vastly improved the region’s living standards in the past few decades. Nevertheless, throughout 
developing Asia demand for more inclusive growth is rising, partly in response to widening 
inequality. 5 More specifically, there are growing calls for governments to play a more direct role 
in narrowing disparities and helping disadvantaged groups. Government intervention to promote 
more inclusive growth depends heavily on fiscal policy, e.g., government spending programs 
that benefit the poor and progressive taxation to generate sufficient revenue fairly. 
 
5.  Another topic that has become important for developing Asia is in the area of global 
supply chains (GSCs) and trade in value added. The fragmentation of production processes and 
the  rise  of  GSCs  since  the  1980s  have  become  increasingly  important  factors  in  linking 
developing  countries  to  international  production  networks  and  markets.  A  large  share  of

III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
6.  The impact of the TA will be for the ADO to influence the environment within which policy 
formulation in selected DMCs occurs. The outcome will be citations of the ADO by the media 
and by economic researchers within ADB and beyond. Appendix 2 contains the outline of ADO 
2014 and ADO 2014 Update. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
7.  The main outputs of the TA will be the disseminated ADO 2014, ADO 2014 Update, and 
ADO  Supplement  reports.7 The  TA  will  support  the  following  key  activities:  (i)  preparing 
background analytical papers; (ii) further developing and refining analytical methods; (iii) drafting 
ADO content; (iv) economic editing and copyediting; (v) preparing and laying out materials for 
publication; and (vi) disseminating key results and policy messages. The TA will also support 
initiatives to build capacity for macroeconomic modeling, generating growth projections, and 
monitoring markets. These initiatives will be linked to a bigger plan within the Economics and 
Research  Department  (ERD)  to  build  a  “modeling  culture”  within  ADB,  and  will  include 
economists in the regional departments, especially those involved in preparing the country 
chapters, and possibly the Office of Regional Economic Integration. Several activities for the 
preparation of ADO 2015 may be supported under the TA.  
 
8.  Continuous effort should be exerted to improve the analytical rigor and policy relevance 
of the reports if they are to remain a credible, independent source of knowledge and information 
about  Asia  and the  Pacific.  Background  research  papers  to  provide a  solid  empirical  and 
analytical  foundation  for  ADO  content  will  be  produced  under  the  TA.  These  papers  will 
supplement the research of the Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division (ERMF) on 
the selected theme topics, analyzing issues and policy implications for the DMCs covered. 
These papers will be consolidated in an edited research volume to provide researchers with 
more extensive background information and analyses related to the theme topic. The research 
volume may be copublished with a reputable publishing house and will likely entail a buyback 
arrangement. 
 
9.  Building on the recommendations of ADO 2012: Confronting Rising Inequality in Asia, 
the theme chapter for ADO 2014 will focus on fiscal policy for inclusive growth. The ADO 2014 
theme  chapter  will  analyze  the  current  state  of  the  relationship  between  fiscal  policy  and 
inclusive  growth  in  the  region,  considering,  for  example,  whether  taxation  is  generally 
progressive and whether government programs promote equality. It will study the international 
experience of the relationship between fiscal policy and inclusive growth in advanced countries 
and Latin America. Advanced countries have a long history of using fiscal policy to reduce 
poverty and inequality, and Latin America offers some interesting case studies of, for example, 
conditional cash-transfer schemes. Based on the analysis of current fiscal policy in the region 
and international experience, policy lessons will be drawn to guide developing Asia’s policy 
makers on how best to leverage fiscal policy for more inclusive growth. Of utmost importance for 
                                                
7  The ADO Supplement is a short report prepared by the Regional Economic Outlook Task Force to provide 
quarterly updates of macro forecasts between ADO and ADO Update releases.

3 
Asia are fiscal policies that enhance inclusion without compromising fiscal sustainability or 
economic growth.  
 
10.  ADO 2014 Update will build on the results of research and development TA on Global 
Supply Chains and Trade in Value Added. The Update’s theme chapter will focus on answering 
two questions of relevance for Asia’s involvement in the global supply chains (GSCs): (i) How 
have GSCs affected trade and production in Asia, and what does this say about the future of 
Factory Asia? (ii) How do GSCs help to transmit supply and demand shocks across countries, 
and do they magnify or dampen these shocks?  
 
11.  The theme will focus on issues such as the development and future of Factory Asia, 
GSCs and occupational transitions in Asia, the GSC linkages at the corporate level with detail 
on geography and company type, and the impact of GSCs on macro phenomena like the 
narrowing of global imbalances. The theme will also look at the relationship between GSCs and 
macro stability by analyzing the intensity with which a GSC demand or supply shock transmits 
across borders; the relative quantitative importance of demand shocks in explaining changes in 
Asian trade and output during several recent downturns; the effect of natural disasters on trade, 
emphasizing  failures  in  supply  chains  as  the  potential  transmission  mechanism;  and  the 
vulnerability of production in Asia to other shocks. 
 
12.  The  TA  will  support  the  development  and  refinement  of  analytical  methods  to 
supplement ADB’s short- and medium-term country economic monitoring and reporting. This will 
strengthen the economic underpinnings of country programs and strategies for the DMCs, 
thereby making economic policies better informed and designed and enhancing ADB’s country 
assistance. 
 
13.  Workshops and conferences will be organized as part of ADO preparation to strengthen 
the content. The writers’ workshop, which will be co-organized with the HR Policy and Programs 
Division, will focus on macroeconomic analysis of current issues, growth accounting, economic 
projections and macroeconomic modeling, and effective writing skills. The workshop will target 
selected economists and national staff in regional departments and resident missions who are 
responsible for writing the country chapters. This will impart skills that are of broader relevance 
to the economic and sector work that underpins country strategies. The conferences will focus 
on the reports’ theme chapters. Distinguished economists in the region will be invited to discuss 
initial drafts of the background papers to improve the analytical rigor and policy relevance of the 
theme chapters. 
 
14.  To ensure accuracy, coherence, and consistency in approach across the ADO and the 
edited volume of background research papers, high-quality editing services will be provided by 
international consultants. 
 
15.   The publications will be widely disseminated in collaboration with the Department of 
External Relations (DER). The international media launch will be followed by presentations 
cohosted by ADB development partners within and outside Asia and the Pacific. Outreach will 
include analytical discussions of the issues in partnership with academic institutions and think 
tanks.

4   
C.  Cost and Financing 
16.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). The cost estimates and financing plan are 
in Appendix 3. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
17.  ADB will be the executing agency, responsible for implementing and monitoring the TA. 
Given the high institutional profile of the ADO, the chief economist will report to the vice-
president for knowledge management and sustainable development and to the President at 
critical points in the publications’ preparation. The TA is expected to start in September 2013 
and be completed by 30 June 2015. 
 
18.  The production of the ADO will be a joint effort (led by ERMF) of ERD economists, 
country  economists  of  the  regional  departments  and  resident  missions,  national  experts, 
international consultants, and economics editorial advisors. As in previous years, ERMF will 
collaborate with regional departments and resident missions to prepare the country chapters. 
For the theme chapters, experts within ADB will be consulted. ERD may explore institutional 
partnerships  with  global  centers  of  excellence  if  appropriate.  For  example,  the  East–West 
Center of the United States, which leads the national transfer accounts database project, is a 
potential institutional partner, especially on fiscal sustainability and economic growth dimensions. 
For global supply chains and trade in value added, ERD has been exploring the opportunity for 
joint work with the Fung Global Institute. The research output of the collaboration with this 
regional center of excellence will be tailored to provide the policy focus of the Update’s theme 
chapter.  
 
19.  The TA will require 18 person-months of international consultancy from economists who 
will prepare the background papers and analyses on issues pertaining to the theme topic. In 
addition, the TA will require an estimated 25 person-months of international economic advisory 
and editing consultants’ time for the economic and technical editing of ADO manuscripts before 
the final publication of ADO 2014 and ADO 2014 Update. The TA will also require 7 person-
months  of  national  economic  consultants’  time  to  assist  in  conducting  research  on 
macroeconomic topics, and another 6 person-months will be needed for the desktop publishing 
and graphic design requirements of the publication. Consultants will be hired as individuals.8 
Resource persons will be engaged for a maximum of 10 working days to conduct training on 
macroeconomics and economic forecasting and may also serve as discussants during the 
workshops.  Consultants  and  resource  persons  will  be  engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). The outline terms 
of reference for the consultants and resource persons are in Appendix 4.  
  
20.  The TA will finance the procurement of information and knowledge services such as 
subscription to macroeconomic data providers as may be required to inform relevant and up-to-
date  content.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  accord  with  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Information and knowledge 
services will be procured in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2013, as amended 
from time to time). 
                                                
8  The TA will involve independent studies and require the rapid mobilization of consultants to ensure that there are 
no delays in the publications’ tight production schedules. In addition, the experience and qualifications of the 
individual consultants will be the primary considerations. Thus, the consultants will be hired on an individual basis.

5 
 
21.  Workshops will be conducted to review and discuss the initial country chapters and 
background papers prepared for the ADO. They are tentatively scheduled for December 2013, 
February 2014, May 2014, and July 2014 at ADB headquarters. The TA may cover travel 
expenses of selected resident mission staff participating in the workshops as resource persons. 
 
22.  The TA will support dissemination by ERD and DER. The major results and key policy 
messages emerging from ADO 2014 and ADO 2014 Update will be disseminated to the media, 
DMC policy makers, and academic communities. The media launch and subsequent roadshows 
will be undertaken by ERD in coordination with DER. Separate launches will be undertaken by 
resident missions in selected DMCs in coordination with their regional departments and DER. 
Roundtable discussions and workshops in different academic and economic institutions will also 
be conducted to reach a wider audience. Both ADO 2014 and ADO 2014 Update will be 
featured on the ADB website, and copies, either in print or on CD-ROM, will be distributed 
worldwide. ADO Supplement reports will be produced in between the publication of the ADO 
and the ADO Update to provide updated assessment on the DMCs. The TA may also support 
the translation of the ADO into other languages, as may be required, to support dissemination in 
selected DMCs. This will be arranged by regional departments in coordination with resident 
missions and DER. 
 
23.  As team leader, the assistant chief economist (ACE), ERMF will monitor the work under 
the  TA  to  ensure  its  effective  implementation.  ERD  researchers  will  review  the  work  of 
consultants  engaged  to  verify  that  tasks  are  completed  in  accordance  with  the  terms  of 
reference and that draft reports are delivered on time, with the ACE, ERMF managing the 
combined outputs of the consultants. Peer review of papers within ADB and, if possible, by 
other research and academic institutions will be used to evaluate the quality and depth of 
analysis of the research papers. The ACE, ERMF will set the production schedule; assure that 
adequate  staff  are  assigned;  and  be  responsible  for  meeting  the  deadlines  for  the  timely 
delivery of publications. The success of dissemination will be monitored through web download 
statistics and media monitoring reports provided by DER. 
 
24.  Outputs and outcomes will be evaluated to measure the success of the TA. ERMF 
evaluation  of  the  overall  ADO  process  will  be  conducted  to  determine  strengths  and 
weaknesses as well as areas for improvement that will serve as inputs for the next ADO. 
Monitoring and back-to-office reports on the ADO and ADO Update launches will also be 
reviewed to gather feedback on the publications and learn lessons from them. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
25.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis 
for the Asian Development Outlook 2014, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Economics Consultants (international, 18 person-months, 13 consultants) 
1.  The consultants should have excellent working experience in general macroeconomics 
(particularly specializing on fiscal policy and issues pertaining to global supply chains and trade 
in value added) and good knowledge of developing member country economies. Under the 
direct supervision of the relevant Macroeconomics and Finance Research Division (ERMF) staff, 
the consultants will 
(i)  prepare analysis essays on fiscal policy and issues pertaining to global supply 
chains and trade in value added, as well as country case reports as may be 
assigned; 
(ii)  participate in Asian Development Outlook (ADO) workshops as may be required; 
(iii)  work with the economics editor to ensure consistency and coherence in the ADO; 
(iv)  deliver the following outputs: draft, revised, and final background papers; and   
(v)  perform  all  other  functions  and  responsibilities  as  may  be  assigned  by  the 
assistant chief economist of ERMF (ACE, ERMF). 
 
B.  Editorial Economic Advisors (international, 19 person-months, 8 consultants) 
2.  Under  the  direct  supervision  of  ACE,  ERMF  and  in  coordination  with  other  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) staff involved in preparing the country chapters of ADO 2014 and 
ADO 2014 Update, the advisors will collaborate with country chapter authors to develop country 
chapter write-ups and review the draft chapters for economic content and consistency with 
economic theory. The advisors will draft the subregional highlights of the publication and ensure 
that all the data in the publication are based on the most recent information available as of the 
specified cutoff date. The advisors will act as resource persons in the ADO writers’ workshop to 
be held at ADB headquarters, working with authors to develop the chapter storylines and 
indicative key messages. In particular, the advisors will 
(i)  work with the country chapter authors during the ADO workshop to develop 
chapter outlines, key messages, and storylines of country chapters; 
(ii)   work  with  the  country  authors  on  drafting,  revising,  and  finalizing  the  texts; 
reviewing them; conducting one-on-one and group discussions with the authors; 
and advising on areas that can be strengthened and improved;  
(iii)   draft subregional highlights and/or summaries, as well as related key messages; 
(iv)  review the validity and accuracy of information, tables, and charts included in the 
write-up; 
(v)  work with the manuscript editor to finalize the text of the country chapters in 
consultation with the authors; 
(vi)  review press releases and related materials for ADO;  
(vii)  deliver the following outputs: edited country chapters and highlights; and 
(viii)  perform all other functions and responsibilities as may be assigned by ACE, 
ERMF. 
 
C.  Manuscript Editor (international, 6 person-months, 1 or 2 consultants) 
 
3.  Under the direct supervision of ACE, ERMF, and in coordination with the relevant ERMF 
staff, the manuscript editor(s) will 
(i)  edit  the  ADO,  including  (a)  rewriting,  reorganizing,  or  shortening  the  text  to 
improve its logical structure and sharpen the arguments; (b) simplifying technical 
language, eliminating jargon, and introducing definitions so that the chapters can

(ii)  check  the  manuscript  for  consistency  and  accuracy,  including  checking  for

chapters, ensuring that queries are addressed, and ensuring that benchmarks

(iii)  copyedit all parts of the reports in conformity with ADB editorial style and usage; 
(iv)  smooth out the entire structure of the publications to make them readable with a 
consistent logical flow; 
(v)  ensure, to the degree possible, consistency of language style in all parts of the 
publication; 
(vi)  edit tables and figures; 
(vii)  ensure that subheads are consistent and logical; 
(viii)  check references to tables, figures, appendixes, bibliographies, and parts of the 
text; 
(ix)  edit notes to make sure that the text references are correct; 
(x)  supervise the encoding of corrections as well as the incorporation of tables, 
charts, and boxes; 
(xi)  prepare the table of contents, definition of terms, and list of abbreviations; 
(xii)  edit all dissemination materials including press releases, speeches, questions 
and answers, key messages, and presentation slides;  
(xiii)  liaise with the typesetter designated by ERMF to ensure that all editorial marks 
and comments, as well as tables, charts, and boxes, are incorporated in the 
typeset manuscript, and that the manuscript is ready for submission for final 
printing;  
(xiv)  deliver the following output: edited manuscript; and 
(xv)  perform all other functions as may be assigned by ACE, ERMF. 
 
D.  Resource Persons (0.6 person-months, 6 experts) 
 
4.  Selected staff of resident missions will be invited as resource persons during the ADO 
writers’ workshop, to present and discuss current country conditions toward the drafting of the 
ADO country chapters. 
 
5.  Resource persons from local institutions and offices of international organizations in the 
region with knowledge of theme chapter topics will be engaged to act as discussants during 
ADO theme conferences.  
 
E.  Desktop Publishing Specialist and/or Graphic Designer (national, 6 person-months, 1 or 
2 consultants)
